title: Security Risk Explorer
text:
Motive-Based Risk Analysis
This part of the dashboard zooms in on why these attacks happen. Instead of just showing where and how often incidents occur, this section explores the underlying motives behind the violence—like political agendas, economic pressures, or just random, incidental chaos.

What You Can Do Here

Filter by Motive: Pick from a dropdown (e.g., Political, Economic, etc.) to see how that motive impacts everything else on the dashboard.
Danger Score Bar Chart: This plot gives a quick overview of which motives are associated with the highest overall danger. It adds up the total impact based on how many people were killed, kidnapped, or wounded.
Risk Map: Once you’ve chosen a motive, the map shows you where related incidents happened around the world. The most dangerous ones are flagged with big red arrows so you don’t miss them.
Top Countries Table: A ranked list of countries most affected by the selected motive—sorted by things like total deaths, kidnappings, and danger scores.


⚠️ Heads up: When looking at political motives specifically, the data gets real. Countries like Afghanistan, Somalia, and Syria show high levels of danger, with hundreds of aid workers either killed or kidnapped over the years. It’s not just numbers, it’s a pattern of risk that speaks volumes about the local instability.

This analysis helps paint a clearer picture of what kind of environments humanitarian workers are stepping into. Whether it’s for mission planning, safety briefings, or just better awareness, understanding motives adds a whole new layer to the conversation around aid work and global security.

title: Humanitarian Risk Dashboard
text:
Humanitarian Risk Advisory Dashboard
The Humanitarian Risk Advisory Dashboard is a web-based application developed to assist humanitarian field teams, UN personnel, NGOs, and analysts in making safer, data-informed travel and deployment decisions. Built on a robust dataset of over 4,000 recorded incidents involving humanitarian actors from 1997 to 2025, this tool enables users to explore where and how these risks have emerged over time.

Features and Capabilities
Time Filtering: Users can interactively adjust the timeline using a slider, allowing them to examine incident patterns across specific periods.
Keyword Search: A flexible search field lets users filter incidents based on terms like “bomb,” “school,” or “convoy,” providing quick access to relevant events.
Global Incident Map: The interactive map offers a geographical overview of incidents, categorized by type—fatalities, kidnappings, sexual violence, and other threats—helping users assess location-specific risks.
Risk Summary Panel: A year-by-year bar chart shows a clear upward trend in humanitarian-related violence over the last two decades, underscoring the growing need for better preparedness.
Risk Level Classification: Countries are assigned a risk score and labeled as high, moderate, or low risk. The score is calculated using the formula:
Risk Score = Deaths × 3 + Kidnaps × 2 + Rapes × 1
This scoring system provides a standardized framework to compare relative danger across regions. While rape is a deeply inhumane and absolutely unacceptable act, the weighting in this formula reflects the immediate and irreversible impact of loss of life in the context of operational security planning. From a humanitarian and logistical standpoint, mortality poses the highest risk to mission continuity, followed by kidnappings, which may lead to prolonged hostage situations and political fallout. Although rape carries tremendous physical and psychological harm, it is assigned a lower weight strictly for risk prioritization purposes, not as a measure of severity or moral judgment. This design helps aid organizations and security teams make informed, pragmatic decisions when assessing safety in volatile regions.

Warning
The rate of violent attacks against humanitarian personnel has steadily increased over the past 20 years. Countries such as Sudan, the Occupied Palestinian Territories, and DR Congo have consistently emerged as high-risk zones.



Why It Matters
This dashboard is more than just a visualization tool—it is a strategic asset. Field coordinators can use it to plan safer routes. Organizations can use it to determine where to allocate resources. Individual travelers can gain a clearer picture of what they might face on the ground. It brings together complex data and presents it in a form that informs real-world decision-making, grounded in evidence.
Above all, this application is designed with a simple goal: to help ensure that those who step into the world’s most dangerous places do so with better awareness, preparation, and protection.


Observations from the Visualization and Ethical Considerations

Looking at the overall incident map, it’s hard to miss the fact that most of the violence is concentrated in regions like the Middle East and parts of East and Central Africa. It’s important to recognize that this isn’t about labeling or stereotyping any country or community. The data simply reflects where humanitarian organizations have faced the most threats over the years. These patterns are likely tied to long-standing conflicts, political instability, and other complex local factors. We have to be careful not to let data turn into bias. Just because an area shows a high number of incidents doesn’t mean it should be unfairly judged, it means those working in those regions need better support, protection, and awareness of the risks they might face.

title: Introduction on the Dataset
text:
In the complex landscapes of conflict zones and fragile states, humanitarian organizations often operate on the edge of danger. While their missions are rooted in peace, protection, and aid, their presence can inadvertently place them in harm’s way. Over the past few decades, hundreds of incidents involving humanitarian personnel have unfolded across the globe — from ambushes and kidnappings to roadside bombings and politically motivated attacks. These incidents are not just isolated events; they reflect broader patterns of instability, insecurity, and geopolitical tension.
This project was born out of a desire to transform raw incident data into meaningful insights. Rather than simply reporting where and when violence occurred, this analysis asks deeper questions: What are the motives behind these attacks? Which countries face the greatest risk? Are some types of violence more prevalent under specific circumstances? Using historical data from over 4,000 recorded security incidents, I want to uncover the underlying patterns and stories hidden within.
The primary motivation behind this visualization is twofold. First, it seeks to uncover and display the global distribution of humanitarian-related security incidents in a way that is both accessible and interactive. By mapping and analyzing the data through visual storytelling, users can immediately grasp the geographic concentration, severity, and patterns of violence against humanitarian actors across time. This allows stakeholders to not only identify hotspots, but also to understand the evolving nature of risks in different regions.
Second, and more critically, this dashboard is designed to function as a travel and risk advisory tool for international personnel such as United Nations staff, NGO workers, and humanitarian responders. By incorporating motive-based filters, severity scores, and dynamic temporal insights, the platform offers actionable intelligence for field planning and mission readiness. This project turns raw data into foresight — helping those who step into danger zones do so with greater awareness, preparedness, and protection.


Code
# Load libraries
library(tidyverse)

# Read in the dataset
df <- read_csv("security_incidents.csv")

# Summarize total killed, wounded, and kidnapped by country
summary_df <- df %>%
  filter(!is.na(Country)) %>%
  group_by(Country) %>%
  summarise(
    Killed = sum(`Total killed`, na.rm = TRUE),
    Wounded = sum(`Total wounded`, na.rm = TRUE),
    Kidnapped = sum(`Total kidnapped`, na.rm = TRUE)
  ) %>%
  mutate(Total = Killed + Wounded + Kidnapped) %>%
  arrange(desc(Total)) %>%
  slice_head(n = 10)

# Convert to long format for ggplot
plot_data <- summary_df %>%
  select(Country, Killed, Wounded, Kidnapped) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = -Country, names_to = "Type", values_to = "Count")

# Plot
ggplot(plot_data, aes(x = reorder(Country, -Count), y = Count, fill = Type)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  labs(
    title = "Top 10 Countries by Total Humanitarian Incident Impact",
    x = "Country",
    y = "Number of People Affected",
    fill = "Impact Type"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))





Let’s take a quick look on the dataset.
This visualization highlights the top ten countries most affected by humanitarian security incidents based on the total number of individuals killed, wounded, or kidnapped. By stacking these three impact types, the chart presents a comprehensive view of the human cost associated with each location. Countries like Afghanistan, South Sudan, and the Occupied Palestinian Territories clearly stand out, underscoring the persistent volatility and danger faced by humanitarian workers in those regions. This visualization not only reveals the severity of the threats but also provides a powerful foundation for understanding where interventions, policy support, and protective measures may be most urgently needed. It serves as a crucial entry point into the broader analysis of global humanitarian risks.
Attacks against United Nations personnel and international humanitarian staff are not only unacceptable — they are inhumane. These individuals dedicate their lives to delivering aid, promoting peace, and supporting vulnerable communities around the world. When they become targets of violence by terrorist organizations or armed groups, it represents a grave violation of international humanitarian principles. Such actions threaten not only the safety of those on the front lines but also the integrity of global humanitarian efforts as a whole. This project aims to highlight the urgency of protecting those who protect others — and to bring data-driven awareness to the global patterns of risk they face.
